I'm on commit 92a2d03740af5cd11d0599c8fc16d8a52132761e from Sep 3rd. and I can confirm I get an issue so #3055 didn't solve the issue.
I'm running the neural-style sample and I'm getting 👍 

> (venv) ➜  neural-style git:(master) ✗ python run.py

> [18:38:57] /Users/yosit/git/mxnet/dmlc-core/include/dmlc/logging.h:235: [18:38:57] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:306: [18:38:57] src/storage/./pooled_storage_manager.h:67: Memory allocation failed.
> An fatal error occurred in asynchronous engine operation. If you do not know what caused this error, you can try set environment variable MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE to NaiveEngine and run with debugger (i.e. gdb). This will force all operations to be synchronous and backtrace will give you the series of calls that lead to this error. Remember to set MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE back to empty after debugging.
> libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type dmlc::Error: [18:38:57] src/engine/./threaded_engine.h:306: [18:38:57] src/storage/./pooled_storage_manager.h:67: Memory allocation failed.

If you do not know what caused this error, you can try set environment variable MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE to NaiveEngine and run with debugger (i.e. gdb). This will force all operations to be synchronous and backtrace will give you the series of calls that lead to this error. Remember to set MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE back to empty after debugging.
> [1]    34843 abort      python run.py
please do a two phase change. Firs move the files, then change the content. I think we can remove nn_op and tensor_op to nn and tensor
Travis compile failed

Yes, I got same error when I run neural art demo.  And this demo runs good under CPU mode. And other demo runs good both under CPU mode and GPU mode.

After reviewing the src code, I think this error is thrown during processing the function MXExecutorBindEX in C_api.cc. 

However, I have not find any solution to fix it.  Can anyone help?

@yosit 

I got same error when I run neural art demo. And this demo runs good under CPU mode. And other demo runs good both under CPU mode and GPU mode.

After reviewing the src code, I think this error is thrown during processing the function MXExecutorBindEX in C_api.cc.

However, I have not find any solution to fix it. Can anyone help?

What I did at the end is to do a custom loop and control the memory release. 

Also instead of using integers, that occupies 32 bits, I used [raw ](http://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-patched/library/base/html/raw.html)vectors, that occupies only 8.

For what its worth I implemented (on the Wolfram fork of MXNet) a ScaledPlus NDArray op that takes two inputs, two scales, and an output and does `out = a*x + b*y` without any allocations. That was needed to make our ADAM optimizer more memory-efficient. I was surprised it wasn't in there already. I would actually like to upstream this at some point.

just use `cudaDeviceEnablePeerAccess` can accelerate things one some hardwares.  using cpu direct, e.g. performing + on two ndarrays on different gpus, seems doesn't improve  the performance comparing to first copy and then execute, but potentially reduce gpu memory usage.

for the latter, we need to disable the context check at https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/operator_util.cc#L886

in this case, we need to set a flag on some place p2p is enabled, so do not check here. any suggestion?
@hoaphumanoid thx

@taliesinb I made a single step adam op here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3225
it will be released with 1.0
Does the symbol use bn and fix-gamma=True into it?
@piiswrong I tested on some examples and haven't got such error. So I would check my code at first. thanks~

warp-ctc only support unified length input feature in a batch.
BTW, warp-ctc can't work well on gpu, you should do some modifications to let it run on cpu only.
I suggest you make batch be one. and using reshape to handle variable size input data.

@tornadomeet sym.get_internals() has no parameters.
@windelu you can use sym.Group to gather the internal layers as outputs.
@starimpact  i just make a mistake, it should be used like this `sym.get_internals()['***_output']`.

@tornadomeet I found it write in 
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/fcn-xs 

> (when using the newest mxnet, you'd better using larger learning rate, such as 1e-4, 1e-5, 1e-6 instead, because the newest mxnet will do gradient normalization in SoftmaxOutput)

But isn't it the default is set to not do the normalization of gradients? I am not clear about the quote sentence means.
I find how the training data was splited. The ImageRecordIter receives param `num_parts` and `part_index` using `kv.num_workers` and `kv.rank`.
@tornadomeet yes, should I use false?
does this issue have an answer??
yes, the mxnet version right now will do it auto, but the model i provide at that time will not.
@Ldpe2G the newset mxnet(will published as 1.0) is not compatibility with pre-trainined model with bn(fix-gamma=True), please refer to this: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3037

Hi @piiswrong 

I add some code into `reshape-inl.h` to debug.

``` c++
224         } else {
225           // great than 0, new shape
226           LOG(INFO) << "new_size:" << new_size << " proposed_dim:" << proposed_dim;
227           CHECK_EQ(new_size % proposed_dim, 0) << "Illegal dim setting, can't be divided. new_size:" << new_size << " proposed_dim:" << proposed_dim;
228           tmp.push_back(proposed_dim);
229           new_size /= proposed_dim;
230           // after set manual shape, can't keep same
231           if (param_.shape.info.size() != dshape.ndim()) {
232             keep = false;
233           } else {
234             src_idx++;
235           }
236         }
237       }
```

And I got these message, it seems that when we train in multi-devices, I guess MXNet would separate data into `num_cpu` chunks(where I can find these model parallel code?). But when we reshape these data, error happen. My `provide_data` shape is (32, 1, 20, 128)

```

[11:56:53] src/operator/./reshape-inl.h:226: new_size:2560 proposed_dim:1

Traceback (most recent call last):

    ctypes.byref(complete)))

    raise MXNetError(py_str(_LIB.MXGetLastError()))
mxnet.base.MXNetError: InferShape Error in reshape_for_embedding: [11:56:53] src/operator/./reshape-inl.h:227: Check failed: (new_size % proposed_dim) == (0) Illegal dim setting, can't be divided. new_size:64 proposed_dim:128
```

sloved, this error is actually equal to the OOM(out of memory) failure. change the arg --max-long-edge when use python command to resize the source jpg as a smaller one. Problem solved.

@yosit 

sloved, this error is actually equal to the OOM(out of memory) failure. change the arg --max-long-edge when use python command to resize the source jpg as a smaller one. Problem solved.
So maybe I should check my DataIter and batch_size and my network definition, in which the batch_size is passed into, so it's static.

I find that cpu verison is more stable than gpu ones when do optimization, it just a feeling.

it's better for multi-machine when you are training large model, like vgg/resnet model on imagenet.

I know the fact  when running ctc in a batch feature length should be the same, 
but between batches the length could be different is this right?

you can use '0' to fit the extra positions to make the label length be same.
yes, you could use different length between batches. but you need to do reshape firstly.

After compile from the source again, no error occur.

``` bash
git pull --recurse-submodules
make -j100
cd python
python setup.py install
```

I solved the problem, I should use -1 to replace batch_size in Reshape operation. :)

After implemented MKL DNN in MXNet, I achieve much better performance with almost the same accuracy. 
The performance data on Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2699 v4 is shown as below chart, gets 2.5x - 3.4x performance.  Now the performance of our framework is competitive with others.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14191863/18277261/6d2a4b04-7480-11e6-962c-17f113365954.png)
Below chart shows the traing curve on cifar10. Result shows my implement can achieve almost the same accuracy.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14191863/18277413/00a56e72-7481-11e6-83cf-3c4f3b3c5833.png)

One problem we need to figure out is, when training cifar10, not matter using base MKL implement or MKLDNN implement, the training speed is only 20+ images/sec. I find the CPU utilization is very low, @hjk41 @tqchen @mli do you have some hints for that problem?

@sbodenstein Great! One potential issue with the existing high-level API implementation is that the models tries to allocate the memory for the reported parameters (separately), instead of continuous chunk of concatenated vector. I guess what seems to be a feasible solution is to let the rnn parameters to have a special name (postfix) so that a customized initializer could recognize it, split it accordingly and do proper initialization.
Closing because of #3161.
LGTM. Can you update the branch?
@pluskid OK.
please do the change, make it compile and let us merge it in. So that later changes can follow without depending on this PR
Change it to something like context compatible checker function.

Since that are A LOT of changes, I propose we do the following way:
- Keep the old files in the original places
- Create new folders, nn, cv, tensor
- After we done a refactor pass of one old file, send a PR to update the file. 
  - Send another PR to move the updated file to new place
Thanks for reporting this! It would be great if you can help us to find out what happens. Can you do a biset on the commit history to see which commit brought in that problem?
Please fix the lint test. Also let us use FlatTo1D in the future for ewise ops
I think it is fine to bring this to master. I will periodically pull the master into nnvm branch. But bring new changes to NNVM branch and push things there could make things easier.

Could you try this latest PR: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3241

Thanks for reporting this. The Julia code lives at https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl which is the right place for issues with the Julia binsings.

How have you build MXNet? Did you build it yourself or with `Pkg.build`? What is the result of `Pkg.status("MXNet")`?
@SevenGong Do you mean it is running correctly now?
LGTM. @yzhang87 can you also take a look at this PR?

OK, must have been confused by the upper/lower case and thought I was in the right place. Shall I close the comment and repost over there? I checked out the master with Pkg.checkout followed by Pkg.build. Pkg.status shows the same in both 0.6 and 0.4.6:

```
Pkg.status("MXNet")
 - MXNet                         0.0.8+             master
```

Let's leave it here for now. Can you send me the `versioninfo()` from 0.4? Did you install julia `v"0.4"` from source or via the package manager? What does `Libdl.dlpath(Libdl.dlopen(Base.libblas_name))` and `Base.blas_vendor()`, return?

```
versioninfo()
Julia Version 0.4.6
Commit 2e358ce* (2016-06-19 17:16 UTC)
Platform Info:
  System: Linux (x86_64-suse-linux)
  CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-4460  CPU @ 3.20GHz
  WORD_SIZE: 64
  BLAS: liblapack.so.3
  LAPACK: liblapack
  LIBM: libopenlibm
  LLVM: libLLVM-3.3
```

Julia 0.4.6 is from an openSUSE yast repo, and Julia 0.6 is from github.
Again in Julia 0.4.6:

```
julia> Libdl.dlpath(Libdl.dlopen(Base.libblas_name))
"/usr/lib64/liblapack.so.3"

julia> Base.blas_vendor()
:unknown
```

`Pkg.build("MXNet")` only supports Julia builds with openblas. Your source build fro v"0.6" uses openblas and so that works without a problem. 
This is sadly an upstream problem with openSUSE, so your best bet is to manually build MXNet (http://dmlc.ml/MXNet.jl/latest/user-guide/install/) or use the generic linux binaries from julialang.org.
OK I will inform openSUSE that there is an issue with their 0.4.6. Thanks much.
LGTM.
let us merge this in once the checks are passed
@piiswrong please fix the issues, and let us bring it in.

The code structure LGTM, 
- the elementwise_op_common can be moved to operator/tensor
- Add inplace option

Please finish all the ewise operators, so that tests pass, and we can bring this in
Since the nnvm branch has been force pushed, you will need to rebase

opensuse really shouldn't be building against reference blas, but they might be doing some funny naming with calling openblas libblas to make it switchable with update-alternatives? That mess isn't really worth the hassle IMO, since openBLAS is so much better or more mature than any other open-source option.
@tqchen Got it
cc @pluskid

@tkelman @vchuravy I went to the openSUSE forum and found other people complaining of problems with -lcblas and failed builds. I also investigated the utility 

```
# update-alternatives --config liblapack.so.3 
There are 4 choices for the alternative liblapack.so.3 (providing /usr/lib64/liblapack.so.3).

  Selection    Path                                  Priority   Status
------------------------------------------------------------
* 0            /usr/lib64/lapack/liblapack.so.3       50        auto mode
  1            /usr/lib64/atlas/libsatlas.so.3        20        manual mode
  2            /usr/lib64/atlas/libtatlas.so.3        20        manual mode
  3            /usr/lib64/lapack/liblapack.so.3       50        manual mode
  4            /usr/lib64/libopenblas_pthreads.so.0   20        manual mode
```

But I have no information about what might be more suitable in the circumstances.
Julia 0.6 works well with MXNet so at this point I am quite happy to blaze away up there, even if the version is a bit unstable.

We can move this discussion elsewhere since it's not a mxnet issue, but the opensuse package for julia should declare a hard dependency on openblas, since building with one implementation and switching to another would likely not work with multithreading. atlas and the reference have not very good performance, and mkl isn't open source so you can't get it from a linux distro.

also can't compiled with gcc4.9 & gcc5
my gcc version
as follows.

```

COLLECT_GCC=gcc

Thread model: posix
gcc version 5.4.0 (GCC)
```

myos: archlinux
cuda7.5

config.mk

```
export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug
DEBUG = 0

# the additional link flags you want to add
ADD_LDFLAGS =

# the additional compile flags you want to add
ADD_CFLAGS =

#---------------------------------------------
# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU
#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile
USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag
# if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE
# USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda
USE_CUDA_PATH = /opt/cuda

# whether use CuDNN R3 library
USE_CUDNN = 1

# whether use cuda runtime compiling for writing kernels in native language (i.e. Python)
USE_NVRTC = 1

# whether use opencv during compilation
# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use
# imbin iterator
USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization
USE_OPENMP = 1

# choose the version of blas you want to use
# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas
# in default use atlas for linux while apple for osx
UNAME_S := $(shell uname -s)
ifeq ($(UNAME_S), Darwin)
USE_BLAS = apple
else
USE_BLAS = atlas
endif

# add path to intel library, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path
# to environment variable
USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

# If use MKL, choose static link automatically to allow python wrapper
ifeq ($(USE_BLAS), mkl)
USE_STATIC_MKL = 1
else
USE_STATIC_MKL = NONE
endif
```

I will transfer this discussion to Julia.
Try [this](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34996295/trying-to-get-cuda-7-5-to-work-with-gcc-5-x)

You can also generate some data like this: 

```
#GENERATE DATA

N = 100 # number of points per class
D = 2 # dimensionality
K = 3 # number of classes
num_examples = N*K
X = matrix(0,num_examples,D) # data matrix (each row = single example)
y = matrix(0,num_examples) # class labels

for (j in 0:(K-1)){
  ix = seq(N*j+1,N*(j+1))
  r = seq(0.0,1,length.out=N) # radius
  t = seq(j*4,(j+1)*4,length.out=N) + rnorm(N)*0.2 # theta
  X[ix,1] = r*sin(t)
  X[ix,2]= r*cos(t)
  y[ix] = j +1
}
# lets visualize the data:
plot(X[, 1], X[, 2], col=rainbow(3)[y])
```

i didn't see any disadvantage yet. updating on device also should be a
little bit faster.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3249

# Operator Registration

The new version of MXNet support operator registration via NNVM, the following code is a snippet on how an operator can be registered.

``` c++
NNVM_REGISTER_OP(abs)
.MXNET_DESCRIBE("Take absolute value of the src")
.set_num_inputs(1)
.set_num_outputs(1)
.set_attr<nnvm::FInferShape>("FInferShape", ElemwiseShape<1,1>);
```

The syntax is quite simple, we register the operator via name, set number of inputs and outputs. Furthermore, we can register additional attributes of the operator.

## Operator Attribute System

One of the biggest improvements brought by the recent refactor is the operator attribute system. This is like traits for types in common languages like c++. We can register arbitrary attribute to any operator, with the syntax

``` c++
NNVM_REGISTER_OP(op-name)
.set_attr<AttributeType>("AttributeKey", CorrespondingAttributeObject);
```

Then these registered operator attribute can be retrieved by the system later for various purposes. For example `FInferShape` attribute is used for shape inference, `FCompute<cpu>` attribute is used for carry out the actual computation on CPU.

We do restrict that all the attributes with same attribute key need to be in the same type. Other than that, we can register any attributes of operators. The more attribute each operator provide, the more information the system can leverage to perform various optimizations.

## A Complete List of Attributed that is used by MXNet

All the operator attributes are listed under two files
- [nnvm/op_attr_types.h](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/include/nnvm/op_attr_types.h)
- [mxnet/op_attr_types.h](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/nnvm/include/mxnet/op_attr_types.h)

## Examples on How to Register Operator Attributes

In this section, we will go through the the attributes that can be registered in an operator. You can find examples of real implementations of operators in [src/operator/tensor](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/nnvm/src/operator/tensor)

An operator can have the following kinds of attributes:

### Attribute Parser (Optional)

Set attribute parser with `.set_attr_parser(PARSER)` where PARSER is a function with prototype `void(nnvm::NodeAttr* attr)`. This function should parse the arguments in `attr->dict` and store the results in `attr->any`.

Simple arguments can be parsed like `.set_attr_parser([](NodeAttrs* attrs) { attrs->parsed = std::stod(attrs->dict["scalar"]); })`.

More complex ops can use `dmlc::Parameters` and ParamParser (defined in operator_common.h) for arg parsing:

``` c++
struct ActivationParam : public dmlc::Parameter<ActivationParam> {
  // use int for enumeration
  int act_type;
  DMLC_DECLARE_PARAMETER(ActivationParam) {
    DMLC_DECLARE_FIELD(act_type)
    .add_enum("relu", activation::kReLU)
    .add_enum("sigmoid", activation::kSigmoid)
    .add_enum("tanh", activation::kTanh)
    .add_enum("softrelu", activation::kSoftReLU)
    .describe("Activation function to be applied.");
  }
};
NNVM_REGISTER_OP(Activation)
.set_attr_parser(ParamParser<ActivationParam>);
```

The parsed arguments can then be accessed in other attribute functions with `double alpha = nnvm::get<double>(attrs.parsed);`

### Number & Name of Inputs/Outputs

Number of inputs/outputs can be set with `.set_num_inputs(n_in)` and `.set_num_outputs(n_out)` where n_in and n_out are integers.

Alternatively, if the number of inputs/outputs is variable and dependent on arguments, you can set n_in/n_out to functions with prototype `uint32_t(const nnvm::NodeAttrs& attrs)` that return the number of inputs/outputs based on parsed arguments.

Outputs can be made invisible by registering `FNumVisibleOutputs`.

Inputs/outputs can be named by registering FListInputNames and FListOutputNames.

### FInferShape or FBackwardOutToInIndex (Backward Only Ops)

Normally operators need to have FInferShape with prototype `bool(const nnvm::NodeAttrs& attrs, std::vector<TShape> *in_attrs, std::vector<TShape> *out_attrs)`. FInferShape fills unknown shapes (shape.ndim() == 0) in in_attrs/out_attrs based on known shapes in in_attrs/out_attrs. Use `ElemwiseShape<n_in, n_out>` for simple operators with uniform shapes.

Operators that are only used for backward pass can instead register FBackwardOutToInIndex with prototype `std::vector<uint32_t>(const NodeAttrs& attrs)`. FBackwardOutToInIndex returns the mapping from backward op outputs to corresponding forward op inputs. Usually this is just {1, 2, ..., n_out } unless the forward op has auxiliary states.

### FInferType

Similar to FInferShape, FInferType fills unknown types (-1) based on known types. Use `ElemwiseType<n_in, n_out>` for simple operators with uniform types.

### Descriptions (Optional)

`.describe(comment)` adds comment to the operator. Use `.MXNET_DESCRIBE(comment)` to add the current file name and line number to comment.

### Argument Descriptions

Set argument descriptions with `.add_argument(name, type, comment)`. This is necessary for operators to be properly called imperatively.

First add NDArray arguments num_inputs times with type "NDArray" or one time with type "NDArray[]" for ops with variable length inputs. Then add float, string, etc, arguments with proper type.

Operators that parse arguments with `dmlc::Parameter` can add argument descriptions with `.add_arguments(ActivationParam::__FIELDS__())`.

### FInplaceOption (Optional)

`FInplaceOption` with prototype `std::vector<std::pair<int, int> >(const NodeAttrs& attrs)` specifies which input/output pairs can optionally share memory. Each pair (i, j) in the returned list means that the i-th input can share memory with the j-th output.

### FGradient (Optional for imperative use, required for symbolic use)

If and operator has gradient, it can be described with `FGradient` with prototype 

``` c++
std::vector<nnvm::NodeEntry>(const nnvm::NodePtr& n,  const std::vector<nnvm::NodeEntry>& ograds)
```

Use utility functions `ElemwiseGradUseIn{op_name}`, `ElemwiseGradUseOut{op_name}`, `ElemwiseGradUseNone{op_name}`  for ops that need corresponding forward op's input, output or nothing to calculating gradient.

For more complicated pattern, use `MakeGradNode(op_name, n, heads)` to create gradient entries, where heads are input entries to backward op, composed from ograds and n->inputs.

### FCompute<xpu> or FCreateLayerOp

Simple operators can register FCompute<xpu> with `.set_attr<FCompute>("FCompute<cpu>", ...)` and `.set_attr<FCompute>("FCompute<gpu>", ...)` for both cpu and (optionally) gpu computation.

FCompute has prototype 

``` c++
void(const nnvm::NodeAttrs& attrs,
        const OpContext& ctx,
        const std::vector<TBlob>& inputs,
        const std::vector<OpReqType>& req,
        const std::vector<TBlob>& outputs)
```

More complex operators that has shared states between forward and backward can instead use the old operator interface by registering FCreateLayerOp with prototype `Operator*(const NodeAttrs& attrs,
                              Context ctx,
                              const std::vector<TShape>& ishape,
                              const std::vector<int>& itype)` that returns pointer to an Operator.

### Example: Absolute value

``` c++
  NNVM_REGISTER_OP(abs)  
  .MXNET_DESCRIBE("Take absolute value of the src")                                     
  .set_num_inputs(1)                                            
  .set_num_outputs(1)                                           
  .set_attr<nnvm::FInferShape>("FInferShape", ElemwiseShape<1, 1>)  
  .set_attr<nnvm::FInferType>("FInferType", ElemwiseType<1, 1>)     
  .set_attr<nnvm::FInplaceOption>("FInplaceOption",                 
    [](const NodeAttrs& attrs){                                 
      return std::vector<std::pair<int, int> >{{0, 0}};         
    })                           
  .set_attr<FCompute>("FCompute<cpu>", UnaryCompute<cpu, mshadow_op::abs>)
  .set_attr<nnvm::FGradient>("FGradient", ElemwiseGradUseIn{"_backward_abs"});                            
  .add_argument("src", "NDArray", "Source input")

  NNVM_REGISTER_OP(_bacward_abs)                                        
  .set_num_inputs(2)                                            
  .set_num_outputs(1)                                           
  .set_attr<nnvm::FInferShape>("FInferShape", ElemwiseShape<2, 1>)  
  .set_attr<nnvm::FInferType>("FInferType", ElemwiseType<2, 1>)     
  .set_attr<nnvm::FInplaceOption>("FInplaceOption",                 
    [](const NodeAttrs& attrs){                                 
      return std::vector<std::pair<int, int> >{{0, 0}, {1, 0}}; 
    })                                            
  .set_attr<FCompute>("FCompute<cpu>",
    BinaryCompute<cpu, unary_bwd<mshadow_op::sign> >);
```
For single machine, update on device might be a bit better, so we might still want to keep the original device aggregation option
